auth.account-already-exists: Someone already has an account with that ID
auth.totp-already-verified: You've already verified your TOTP enrollment
auth.invalid-email: That doesn't quite look like an email address
auth.create-account-first: You must create an accout first

cryption.plaintext-not-json: Decrypted plaintext did not parse as valid JSON: {error}: '{plaintext}'

db.account-has-transactions: Cannot delete an account that has transactions
db.could-not-parse-document: Failed to parse record from server document {id}
db.record-does-not-match-guard: Record does not match '{guard}' type guard

batch.op-limit: Cannot batch more than {limit} write operations
batch.one-db: Must use exactly one database in a write batch

form.missing-required-fields: Please fill out the required fields

fs.invalid-uri-no-byte-string: Invalid Data URI: Could not get byte string
fs.invalid-uri-no-mime-string: Invalid Data URI: Could not get MIME string

network.account-conflict: An account with that ID already exists
network.bad-gateway: The CORS policy for this site does not allow access from the specified Origin
network.bad-method: That method is not allowed here. What are you trying to do?
network.expired-token: You must sign in again in order to proceed
network.missing-mfa-credentials: You must provide a TOTP code
network.not-implemented: That feature is not implemented yet
network.totp-conflict: You already have TOTP authentication enabled
network.totp-secret-missing: You do not have a TOTP secret to validate against
network.unknown: Not sure what went wrong. Try again maybe?

sanity.missing-env-var: No value found for environment variable '{key}'

server.id-not-string: Expected ID to be of type 'string'
server.missing-access-token: Expected access token from server, but got none
server.missing-secret: Expected secret from server, but got nothing
server.no-data: Expected data from server, but got none
server.too-few-documents: Expected an array of documents from server, but got one document
server.too-many-documents: Expected a single document from server, but got an array

settings.missing-db-file: '{filename}' not present at root of zip
settings.invalid-location-preference: '{pref}' is not a valid location preference

storage.invalid-checksum: The uploaded file does not match the provided checksum. Please reupload
storage.no-data-found: No data found at the ref
storage.server-file-wrong-size: The uploaded file does not match the provided file size. Please reupload

ws.not-json: The message could not be parsed as JSON: {message}
ws.server-closed-without-reason: The server closed the connection without telling us why

debug.account-but-no-transaction: We have an account, but no transaction.
debug.count-one-transaction: There is 1 transaction in the cache.
debug.count-all-transactions: There are {n} transactions in the cache.

files.does-not-exist: This file does not exist. Sorry.

list.heading: Files
list.how-to-create: To add a file, attach it to a transaction.

delete.confirm: Are you sure you want to delete {title}? This cannot be undone.

reference.heading: Fix broken reference
reference.explanation: This attachment somehow got lost in the mix, possibly due to an import bug. Select the correct file below:

list.heading: Locations
list.how-to-create: To add a location, set a location on a transaction.

months.does-not-match-pattern: '{month}' does not match a month identifier pattern

auth.account-id-description: Somebody bothering you with your account ID? You can change it with one click:
auth.account-id-updated: Your account ID has been updated!

delete-all.heading: Delete Everything
delete-all.description: You have the option to delete all of your data on {platform}.
delete-all.confirm: Are you sure you want to delete {everything}? This action cannot be undone.

meta.heading: Export
meta.description: Exports an {unencrypted} copy of all your data in JSON format. (Except attachments of course, those will come as {platform} got them).

meta.heading: Import
meta.description: Import a JSON file describing one or more accounts.

import.duplicates-explanation: These entries seem to match an account you already have. Would you like to overwrite the account and transactions we have stored with what you gave us here?
import.heading: Select Accounts from "{fileName}"

location.heading: Location Service
location.api-disclaimer: By default, we don't talk to any external location APIs. However, if you want {platform} to prefill transaction location fields, you'll need to select a different option below.
location.manual-disclaimer: Note that we have no "automatic" location features. We only fetch your current location when you press a button to request it. We use the {iplocate} API to obtain vague location data.

preference.imprecise-description: Get, on-demand, a locale based on your IP address.

general.heading: Multi-factor Authentication
general.explanation: Your passphrase is a single authentication factor ("something you know"). Adding a second factor ("something you have" or "something you are") increases your account's security by, like, a lot.

enroll.heading: Enroll in MFA
enroll.scan-secret: Scan this code with your authenticator app:
enroll.recovery-code-explanation: Here is your recovery token. Keep it safe, somewhere you can get to it if you lose your 2FA auth device:

delete.confirm: Are you sure you want to delete {name}?
delete.removed-from-transactions: This tag will be removed from {count}.

list.heading: Tags
list.how-to-create: To add a tag, go to one of your transactions.

delete.detach-first: You must delete attachments before you may delete this transaction.
delete.confirm: Are you sure you want to delete {title}? This cannot be undone.

locations.disclaimer: To get your current location, you'll need to enable the location service in {settings}.

footer.license: This project is licensed under the {name}.

accountability.heading: Accountable To Yourself.
accountability.p1: Keep a close eye on your spending. Never lose a dime again! If you're the sort to obsess about where your money is going, {tool}.
accountability.tool: this might be the tool for you

encrypted.heading: Your Ledger, Not Mine.
encrypted.p1: {platform}, by design, cannot see your data, even on our own servers. We don't need or want to see what you do with your money. That's not my job. {legal}
encrypted.legal: (I'd rather you {not} do illegal stuff with this.)

open-source.heading: Keep Me Accountable.
open-source.open: All of our source code is open to read.
open-source.pr: Feel free to {issue} or submit a pull request on this project's {github}.
open-source.let-me-know: Let me know if anything needs fixed.

how-we-work.p: {platform} is a {spa} that encrypts and decrypts your data on your own device. This means that our servers cannot know what's in your wallet. This works entirely in the browser, using modern standard JavaScript APIs. You can {read} if you're curious!

login.cookie-disclaimer: Logging in will set two cookies, which together contain information that declares your access to your data. These cookies let your browser securely remember that you are logged in. The alternative is for us to recall your login information with JavaScript, which is not a safe place to keep things. {more}

new-account-prompt.open-soon: Don't have an account? We'll be open for new accounts soon!

new-account.heading: Your New Account
new-account.p1: This is your new account ID. You will need it and your passphrase to log in later.
new-account.no-recovery: If you lose it, we won't be able to get it back for you.
new-account.is-account-id-safe: Do you have your account ID ({accountId}) written down somewhere safe?

locked.heading: Vault locked
locked.explanation: You're logged in, but your ledger is locked. Enter your passphrase to unlock the ledger.

service.heading: Hosted Service
service.p1: There's a hosted {platform} client-server architecture right here! Click the {login} link above to create an account.

self.heading: Self-host Server
self.p1: Check out the {readme} for more on how to set {platform} up on your own computer.
self.planning: We're planning a hosted solution right here soon.
self.p2: I'm toying with the idea of (optionally) using Firebase as a {platform} storage server. This would be great for users who are okay with using a Google service and don't want to pay to host their own installation.

goals.heading: Goals
goals.p1: The aim of {platform} is to be a cross-platform and portable spot to keep your transaction records and receipts. I plan to have proper mobile clients eventually. The {selfhost} option will always be available, and I intend for this project to always be {opensource}. You will always have access to the financial records that you give to {platform}, and {platform} cannot share those records with anyone else.

alternatives.heading: Alternatives
alternatives.p1: There are a few {alts} out there, but none I've found that I like. Lots of proprietary ones, too. Feel free to use them if you'd like, I'm not sponsored by any of them. Their names are trademarks of their respective owners:
alternatives.alt2: {intuit} makes {mint}. These guys also make {turbotax} and other fintech products you might have heard about.
alternatives.alt3: {ramsey} makes {everydollar}. I subscribe to many of Ramsey's financial principles. Stay out of debt, folks.
alternatives.alt4: There are {others}, but I've only tried these. Check them out if you're curious! I'm sure they're great.
alternatives.open-source: I'm sure these are brilliant, but none of them are {opensource}. All of these keep your data for you, and hang onto the encryption keys to that data; they're not {e2ee}. I don't know what all they do with your data, and I don't trust them to tell you.
alternatives.summary: Part of their business model is to be the gateway to your financial records. If you just want help with your budget, and want someone else to keep your pocketbook for you, then any of the above may suit you just fine.

security-faq.heading: Security FAQs
security-faq.summary: {tldr} Your data is unreadable by anyone but you (as far as I know.)

encryption-kind.question: What sort of encryption does {platform} do?
encryption-kind.answer: We use only the best {mge} everyone else uses.

where-keys.question: Who holds the encryption keys?
where-keys.answer2: When you create an account, {platform} generates a data-encryption key {dek} to use to encrypt and decrypt your data. {platform} generates a separate key-encryption key {kek} from your given passphrase to use to encrypt your DEK. {platform} sends the encrypted DEK blob to our servers to store. This encrypted blob is useless without the KEK to decrypt it, and your KEK is unknown without your passphrase.
where-keys.answer3: We use {sha512} and {pbkdf2} with 10,000 rounds to generate these keys. See {source}.

passphrase-handling.question: What does {platform} do with my passphrase?
passphrase-handling.answer1: {platform} never transmits your passphrase anywhere, even over TLS.
passphrase-handling.answer2: {platform} generates a one-way hash of your passphrase, and sends that instead. The server then {salts} and {hashes} that hash, and stores the resulting mash. (That mash has nothing to do with how your data is encrypted; see above.)
passphrase-handling.answer3: When you log in again, {platform} repeats the procedure on your hashed passphrase, and checks to see whether this new mash matches the stored mash.
passphrase-handling.answer4: This mash is what our storage server uses to guard access to your encrypted database. If someone can give the server a passphrase hash that results in the correct mash, the server assumes that person is you, and happily sends over your encrypted data. No part of this mashâ€”the hash the server gets, the salt the server generates, or the final mash of the twoâ€”can be used to decrypt your data. ({platform} uses your {dek} for that; see above.)
passphrase-handling.answer5: We use {sha512} and {bcrypt} with a cost factor of 15. See {source}.

change-passphrase.question: What if I change my passphrase?
change-passphrase.answer1: We don't re-encrypt the entire database, if that's what you're thinking.
change-passphrase.answer2: Since your passphrase is only used to generate a KEK, {platform} only re-encrypts the DEK using the new KEK that your new passphrase generates.
change-passphrase.answer3: If you think your DEK may be compromised, I'm sorry. You may export your data, delete your old account, create a new account, and import your data again. This will re-encrypt everything using a fresh DEK.

lost-passphrase.question: What happens if I lose my passphrase?
lost-passphrase.answer1: You lose your data. There is nothing I or anyone else can do to bring your data back. (That is, unless your passphrase is easily cracked. Give it a go!) Without your passphrase, nobody can generate the KEK that encrypted the DEK that encrypted your data. Without that passphrase, your data is lost.

database-breach.question: What happens if someone steals the database?
database-breach.answer1: If your passphrase is long and complicated, there's nothing that anyone can do with our database. The server never sees your DEK, your passphrase's KEK, or your passphrase. None of those are in the database.
